title: Transcranial Contralateral Routing of Signal for Single-Sided Deafness
chief_complaint: I am exhausted from trying to understand speech, especially in noisy places, and I can't tell where sounds are coming from. I tried a CROS aid before, but it sounded tinny and I hated wearing two devices.

problem_summary.onset: 3 years prior, following acoustic neuroma removal.
problem_summary.laterality: Left profound hearing loss; Right normal hearing.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Fatigue, difficulty localizing sound, difficulty in noise. Denies tinnitus.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Significant fatigue and communication difficulty in complex environments.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Interested in amplification but dissatisfied with previous standard CROS trial; specifically interested in transcranial CROS options.

history.present_illness: Patient had an acoustic neuroma removed from the left ear 3 years ago, resulting in single-sided deafness.
history.otologic_history: Left acoustic neuroma removal. No other history reported.
history.prior_management: Previous trial with standard CROS system was unsuccessful; patient reported poor sound quality ('tinny') and disliked wearing devices on both ears.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal hearing sensitivity in the right ear. Profound sensorineural hearing loss (anacusis) in the left ear.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent word recognition in the right ear. Testing not completed for left ear due to severity of loss.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes present at normal levels. Left ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes absent.

history.present_illness: Follow-up to determine candidacy for transcranial CROS fitting.
history.prior_management: Proceeding with investigation of transcranial fitting.
history.patient_goals: Verify if sound can cross from the poor ear to the good ear via bone conduction.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Unaided transcranial thresholds measured by presenting pure tones to the left (deaf) ear until heard by the right cochlea. Results indicate crossover is achievable at output levels feasible for a high-power hearing aid.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with single-sided deafness (left profound SNHL) and normal hearing in the right ear. Standard CROS was previously rejected. Investigation of transcranial crossover thresholds indicates that high-intensity sound presented to the left ear can successfully cross over to stimulate the right cochlea via bone conduction (transcranial thresholds approx 40-65 dB HL). This profile suggests she is a candidate for a high-power transcranial CROS fitting on the left ear.
counseling_points: A transcranial CROS works by picking up sound on your deaf side and amplifying it so loudly that it travels through the skull bone to your good ear.
Because we need very high volume to vibrate the skull, the hearing aid must fit very tightly. We will need to take a deep ear impression, which might feel full or tight.
Feedback (whistling) is a common challenge with this fitting due to the high power; a tight fit is crucial to prevent this.
This device will not restore true stereo hearing or perfect localization, but it should help you be aware of sounds on your left side.
In very noisy situations where noise is on your bad side, the device might amplify that noise. We can set a program or mute function to help manage this.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is knowledgeable about their condition and frustrated by previous 'standard' solutions.
You have already tried a standard CROS (two devices) and hated itâ€”emphasize that you found the sound 'tinny' and it was annoying to wear something on your good ear.
You are specifically asking for the 'transcranial' option (one powerful aid in the bad ear).
Show fatigue when describing how hard it is to listen in noise.
